content.text: General statements
It has been a real pleasure working with [Name] this [term/quarter/semester/year].
It has been a delight to have [Name] in our class this [term/quarter/semester/year].
[Name] made a smooth transition into [kindergarten/first grade/second grade].
[Name] really enjoyed [his/her] transition into [kindergarten/first grade/second grade]. Each day [he/she] came in with a smile and made a conscious effort to do [his/her] best.
[Name] made [exceptional/good/average/steady] and [exceded/met] expectations for [kindergarten/first grade/second grade] this [term/quarter/semester/year].
[Name] has had many wonderful accomplishments and successes in our class so far this [term/quarter/semester/year]!
It has been a true pleasure and rewarding experience watching [Name] grow this [term/quarter/semester/year].
[Name] exhibited a rare exuberance for and commitment to learning across the subject areas.
[Name] matured academically and socially throughout the school [term/quarter/semester/year].
[His/Her] tenacity, strong focus and commitment to doing [his/her] very best work supported [his/her] academic growth this [term/quarter/semester/year].
[Name] made significant progress this [term/quarter/semester/year].
[Name] continued to have a great year in [kindergarten/first/second] grade.
[Name] had a terrific year in [kindergarten/first/second] grade.
Social/Emotional
Self-regulation
[Name] demonstrated self-control.
[Name] managed [his/her] feelings well.
[Name] consistently made an effort to self-regulate [his/her] own behavior in order to become a knowledgeable student.
[Frequently/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], [Name] was distracted by others, but [he/she] did make an effort to self-regulate [his/her] own behavior.
[Name] needed support to resist distractions.
[Name] [was willing/began/tried hard/struggled] to share and take turns.
Relationships
[Name] was a [sensitive/kind/outgoing/thoughtful/friendly] member of our class.
[Name] was [shy/slow to warm up/bossy/confrontational/aggressive/rough/uncooperative] with classmates.
[Name] was continually sought after by [his/her] peers for partner work, conferencing, or participation in free time activities.
[Name] got along with all of the students in the class, and was sensitive to others’ feelings.
[Name] related well to classmates.
[Name] related well to adults.
[Name] relished individual attention from [his/her] teachers.
Although initially slow to warm up, in time [Name] became more outgoing and made new friendships.
[Name] often volunteered to help others in class, sharing [his/her] knowledge and expertise.
[Name] was helpful to others.
[Name] demonstrated respect and consideration for others.
[Name] enjoyed discussing [his/her] work and readily accepted suggestions from [his/her] teacher and peers.
[Name] showed leadership skills in group work.
[Name] worked well in small groups.
There is an emotional maturity about [Name] that is evident in [his/her] peer interactions and in [his/her] ability to compromise and cooperate to advance a group goal.
[Name] [could be counted on/needed reminders] to follow our essential agreement both in and out of the classroom.
[Name] took our essential agreements to heart, and made a sincere effort to follow them every day.
[Name] served as a model citizen for other students.
[Name] made ethical decisions.
[Name] treated classmates fairly.
[Name] understood that [his/her] actions have an impact on others, which [he/she] demonstrated by ___.
[Name] had a strong sense of [fairness/justice/respect].
[Name] took responsibility for [his/her] actions.
[Name] thought about [his/her] actions and how they affected others.
[Name] had a fair-minded approach to ___.
[Name] demonstrated responsibility.
[Name] accepted responsibility for [his/her] actions.
Always respectful of others, [Name] was eager to cooperate in groups.
[Name] [showed/began to show/sometimes did not show] empathy towards the needs and feelings of others.
[Name] demonstrated personal commitment to service.
[Name] acted to make positive difference to our school environment.
[Name] managed conflicts [independently and appropriately/with a teacher’s help].
[Frequently/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], [Name] needed reminders to keeps [his/her] hands to [himself/herself] and respect others’ personal space.
Though generally sweet-natured, [Name] could be stubborn and inflexible with [his/her] peers.
We worked with [Name] to be open to others’ points of view and adaptable in [his/her] interactions with friends.

[Frequently/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], [Name] found [herself/himself] in difficult social situations. [He/She] was always eager to solve the problems that arose but occasionally needed guidance from a teacher. [Name] has been working on strategies to solve problems effectively.

[Frequently/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], [Name] found [himself/herself] in difficult social situations in which [he/she] became emotionally charged. Very often, [he/she] required teacher assistance in order to solve these problems. In time, [Name] should internalize effective strategies and develop the ability to solve these situations independently.
Work habits
[Name] was a [exceptional/typical/struggling] [kindergartener/first grader/second grader] in [his/her] approach to learning.
[Name] was a [motivated/determined/organized] student.
[Name] approached tasks in an organized manner.
[Name] [completed/needed support to complete] work in a reasonable amount of time.
[Name] focused and used time effectively.
[Name] [was able/needed help] to use time wisely.
[Name] planned and carried out activities effectively.
[Name] organized [his/her] materials.
[Name] required support to organize [his/her] personal belongings and class materials.
[Name] [managed/began to manage] transitions well, such as lining up or walking to a specialist class.
[Name] transferred strategies from group lessons to independent work.
[Name] worked well independently and in small groups.
[Name] showed initiative.
When working independently, [Name] was able to sustain [his/her] focus for extended periods of time and as a result, [he/she] produced high-quality work.
When [Name] didn’t understand something, [he/she] [always/usually/sometimes /rarely] sought help from peers or the teacher.
[Frequently/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], [Name] struggled to listen and follow directions.
At the beginning of [kindergarten/first grade/second grade], [Name] was tentative in [his/her] abilities and needed a teacher to help read the morning message or directions on a worksheet.
[Name] thirsted for individual adult attention to do [his/her] work, but we would like to see [him/her] complete assignments more independently.
It was difficult to tell whether [Name] was reluctant to put forth the work needed on a daily basis, thirsted for individual adult attention to do her work, or struggled with a deeper learning issue.
IB PYP Learner profile and attitudes
[Name] was a [risk-taker/communicator/thinker/inquirer].
[Name] was a [principled/caring/knowledgeable/open-minded/reflective/balanced] student.
[Name] showed [respect/commitment/empathy/independence/confidence/tolerance/ethusiasm/curiousity/appreciation/creativity/integrity/cooperation].
[Name] had tremendous energy and enthusiasm.
[Name] participated whole-heartedly in all classroom activities and projects with enthusiasm.
[Name] had an inquisitive nature and was a keen observer of the world around [him/her].
[Name] showed natural curiosity.
[Name] brought a creative, inquiring mind and adventurous spirit to [his/her] learning.
[Name] creatively expressed [his/her] ideas about ___.
A reflective learner, [Name] was able to assess [her/his] strengths and areas to improve.
[Name] took risks.
[Name] gave thoughtful consideration to [his/her] own learning and experiences.
A risk taker, [Name] [approached unfamiliar situations with courage/
explored new ideas willingly/was willing to make mistakes].
A creative thinker, [Name] was [prepared to try something new/willing to try things in unfamiliar ways].
[Name] was a creative individual.
[Name] was committed to [his/her] learning. Through a great deal of hard work and determination, [he/she] ___.
[Name] was committed to [his/her] learning. [Name] didn’t give up easily.
[Name] showed [excellent/strong/good/growing] confidence in ___.
[Name] showed independence in [his/her] learning.
[Name] was able to make reasonable decisions independently.
[Name] demonstrated excellent thinking skills.
[Name] understood the importance of balance to achieve personal wellbeing.
[Name] exhibited integrity when [he/she] ___.
[Name] exhibited honesty when [he/she] ___.
[Name] made principled decisions.
[Name] worked on becoming a balanced learner by demonstrating confidence in the classroom as well as on the playground making friends.
Concluding statements
[Name] should feel proud of [his/her] progress this [term/quarter/semester/year]!
[Name] was very good-natured and an absolute pleasure to teach. I look forward to a year of continued growth and learning together.
[I/We] look forward to seeing [his/her] continued growth and learning.
[I/We] [am/are] pleased with [his/her] accomplishments.
[Name] is promoted to [Grade 1/Grade 2/Grade 3].
[I/We] wish [him/her] the best in [Grade 1/Grade 2/Grade 3]!
[I/We] wish [him/her] the best at [his/her] new school!
[I/We] wish [him/her] continued success in [his/her] future learning!
It has been [incredible/rewarding] to be a part of [his/hers] [tremendous/steady] growth this [term/quarter/semester/year].
[I/We] will certainly miss seeing [his/her] smiling face next year.
Have a wonderful summer and good luck in [first grade/second grade/third grade]!
Reading
General
In Reading, [Name] demonstrated [exemplary/thorough/good/satisfactory/basic/limited] understanding this semester.
[Name] was a [avid/enthusiastic/steady/determined/reluctant] reader.
[Name] made [excellent/good/adequate] progress this semester.
[Name] [enjoyed reading/read for pleasure].
[Name] could often be found with a book in hand.
[Name] solidified [his/her] skills as a reader this semester.
[Name] continued to develop a love for reading.
[Name] achieved many milestones as a reader.
With [minimal/some] support, [Name] attempted [what?].
[Name] chose just-right books during visits to library.
[Name] sustained focus during read alouds.
[Name] may enjoy books such as [book recommendations].
[I/We] encourage [Name] to continue reading over the summer.
Solving words
[Name] figured out words using strategies such as [describe decoding strategy].
[Name] used multiple strategies to figure out unknown words.
[Name] relied on [his/her] phonetic knowledge to figure out words.
[Name] used familiar parts of words to figure out unknown words.
While [Name] knew strategies to solve words, [he/she] relied heavily on visual cues.
Continued phonics work helped [Name] to more easily identify sounds.
[His/Her] mastery of long and short vowel sounds was increasing.
[Name] built a repertoire of strategies for decoding words and [consistently/when reminded] used them to figure out unfamiliar [one-syllable/multisyllabic] words.
While [Name] had a repertoire of word-solving strategies, [usually/sometimes/occasionally/at times], [he/she] needed support to apply them to new, difficult words.
We are working with [Name] to build [his/her] confidence as a reader and more readily apply word-solving strategies on [his/her] own.
[Name] easily read high-frequency words.
[Name] had a [impressive/large/adequate/growing/limited] vocabulary of high frequency words.
A goal for [Name] is to build [his/her] sight-word recognition and be able to read them without sounding them out. This will help to make [him/her] a more fluent reader.
[Name] figured out the meaning of unknown words from picture clues and context.
Fluency
[Name] read in fluid phrases.
[Name] read books beyond grade level expectations with fluency and expression.
[Name] read primarily word-by-word. We worked to help [him/her] read in more fluent phrases.
[Name] was beginning to read in phrases rather than word by word.
[His/Her] fluency and accuracy were beginning to show signs of growth.
[Name] became a more fluent reader.
[Name] noticed and used punctuation to guide [his/her] reading.
[Name] read words in bold with emphasis.
[Name] noticed quotation marks and adjusted [his/her] reading to reflect an understanding of the dialogue.
It was a pleasure to listen to [Name] read aloud as [he/she] used a great deal of expression and intonation in [his/her] voice.
This was demonstrated in our various readers’ theater performances.
[Name] read familiar books with confidence.
[Name] read silently at a good pace.
[Name] read in different ways as appropriate for the purpose of the text.
[Name] read with expression, attending to information about character’s feelings.
Moving forward, [he/she] should speak in a louder, more confident voice while reading aloud.
Monitoring and correcting
[Name] could tell when something didn’t sound right, and slowed down to reread and correct for meaning.
[Name] self-corrected for meaning as [he/she] read.
[Name] slowed down or repeated words to think about meaning, and then resumed reading a normal pace.
[Name] knew when [he/she] needed more information to understand what [he/she] read.
Comprehension
[Name] was able to summarize stories read aloud or during book groups.
[Name] remembered important information in the stories [he/she] read.
[Name] described characters, settings, and major events in a story.
[Name] used illustrations and details in a story to describe its characters, setting, or events.
[Name] could identify a problem and solution in the stories [he/she] read.
[Name] determined the central message, lesson, or moral of the stories [he/she] read.
[Name] was able to identify a character’s point of view or defining attributes.
[Name] used [his/her] background knowledge to understand characters and their problems.
[Name] was able to make predictions about what might happen next.
[Name] was able to make predictions by using what is known to think about what might happen.
[Name] used evidence in the book to support the predictions [he/she] made.
[Name] could figure out what a character might be thinking or feeling, using the text to provide evidence.
[Name] was able to talk about characters’ feelings and motivations.
[Name] used relevant personal connections to understand the books [he/she] read.
[Name] made connections between the books [he/she] read and other books [he/she] knew.
[Name] used prior knowledge and experience to make connections.
[Name] made text-to-text, test-to-self, and/or text-to-world connections.
[Name] read to learn and demonstrated new understanding after reading.
[Name] was able to talk about how [his/her] ideas changed after reading a book.
[Name] applied [his/her] prior knowledge to understand books.
[Name] able to make inferences and draw conclusions using supporting details from the book.
[Name] was usually able to recall the main events from books [he/she] read but [frequently/sometimes/occasionally/at times], struggled to make inferrences.
While [Name] demonstrated a very good literal understanding of the books [he/she] read, [he/she] worked to develop [his/her] ability to make inferences and draw conclusions about them.
[Name] went beyond the literal meaning of the text to think about what is not stated directly but implied by the author.
[Name] supported [his/her] thinking with specific examples from the books [he/she] read.
Analyzing and critiquing
[Name] demonstrated an understanding of how books work. For example, [he/she] knew that nonfiction books use a combination of pictures, captions, and text to convey meaning.
[Name] understood the difference between fiction and nonfiction texts.
[Name] had favorite authors and illustrators and could tell why [he/she] liked them.
[Name] was able to notice words an author used to make a story more interesting.
[Name] noticed when a book was funny or suprising.
[Name] could talk about what made the characters interesting.
[Name] talked about how characters might have behaved differently.
[Name] began to give opinions about the books [he/she] read.
[Name] shared [his/her] opinions about books and told why.
Book group participation
[Name] actively participated in book discussions.
[Name] communicated effectively with [his/her] book group.
[Name] was able to reference the text during book talks.
[Name] performed in a readers’ theater presentation of [book title].
Through our guided reading group discussions, [Name] began to develop the ability to think more deeply about a book.
Writing
General
[Name] was an enthusiastic writer who seemed to greatly enjoy the craft of writing.
[Name] enjoyed creating [his/her] own stories during Writers’ Workshop.
[Name] was a prolific writer.
[Name] enjoyed writing narratives.
As a writer, [Name] approached tasks with enthusiasm but needed encouragement to add length and details to [his/her] work.
[Name] benefited from frequent check-ins with a teacher.
[Name] was a reluctant writer who benfited from one-on-one coaching and encouragement from the teacher.
Once [he/she] had an idea of what to write, [he/she] could better see [his/her] piece to completion.
The one-on-one support [Name] received proved very helpful as [Name] was reluctant when it was time to write independently.
The one-on-one support [he/she] received from [Learning support specialist] helped [Name] develop [his/her] ideas and add length and detail to [his/her] writing.
[Name] made great strides as a writer this [term/quarter/semester/year] and overall [he/she] more readily put a pencil to the paper.
Genre study
[Name] demonstrated a [excellent/very good/good/basic] understanding of the [narrative/informational/persuasive] genre.
[Name] wrote narratives in which [he/she] recounted an event or short sequence of events.
[Name] wrote nonfiction “teaching” texts to tell about a topic.
[Name] wrote opinion pieces in which [he/she] introduced the topic, stated an opinion, listed reasons to support the opinion.
[Name] experimented with writing chapter books.
Voice
[Name] developed voice in [his/her] writing.
[Name] expressed [his/her] feelings through words and punctuation.
[Name] expressed [his/her] feelings through pictures.
[Name] showed individual expression in [his/her] writing.
[Name] began to show awareness of the audience in [his/her] writing.
[Name] engaged with [his/her] audience by asking questions.
[His/her] voice developed this semester and we encourage [him/her] to continue to show sparks of personality in [his/her] stories.
[His/Her] sense of humor came through in [his/her] writing.
The voice [Name] developed as a writer was inspiring.
Ideas
[Name] had many compelling ideas.
[Name] generated own ideas in writing with ease.
[Name] generated own ideas in writing with support.
[His/Her] writing demonstrated well-developed ideas.
[Name] stayed focused on the topic of [his/her] writing.
The big idea behind [his/her] writing was clear, and [he/she] stayed on topic.
[Name] wrote details to support [his/her] ideas.
[His/Her] writing was usually limited to one sentence or repeated ideas. With support, [he/she] was [able to/began to] add on.
[His/Her] ideas were at times unclear, and [he/she] needed to explain them for the writing to make sense.
Organization
[Name] benefited from conferencing with a teacher at the beginning of a writing project in order to help develop a plan for [his/her] story.
[Name] wrote strong leads.
[Name] attended to the elements of a story (problem, solution, characters).
[Name] effectively organized [his/her] writing into a beginning, middle and end.
[Frequently/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], the sequence of events in [his/her] writing was unclear or confusing.
[Name] used transition words (then, after that, finally) to form fluent sentences.
[Name] used linking words (e.g., because, and, also) to connect opinion and reasons.
[Name] experimented with endings.
[Name] provided a sense of closure in a concluding sentence or paragraph.
With support, [he/she] was able to write an ending to provide a sense of closure.
[Name] was able to craft a specific, unique ending in [his/her] writing.
Word choice
[Name] used creative and expressive words.
[Name] experimented with new vocabulary and bigger words.
[Name] chose words that made sense.
[Name] used words correctly.
[Name] used verbs that described exact actions.
[Name] described thoughts and feelings in [his/her] writing.
[Name] used sensory language for details.
[Name] demonstrated a large vocabulary which [he/she] applied effectly to [his/her] writing.
[Name] experimented with figurative language.
[Name] used figurative language to convey meaning.
[Name] relied on words [he/she] knew well when writing.
Sentence fluency
[Name] developed sentence fluency.
[Name] wrote sentences that varied in length.
[His/Her] writing was smooth and easy to read.
[Usually/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], it was difficult for [him/her] to read [his/her] own writing aloud.
[Usually/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], it was difficult for the teacher to read [his/her] writing aloud.
[Name] had basic subject-verb agreement in [his/her] sentences.
[Name] worked to develop an awareness of where sentences begin and end.
[Name] experimented with dialogue in [his/her] writing.
Conventions
[Name] consistently used grade-appropriate conventions, such as periods, capital letters, and spaces.
[Name] used conventional spelling for basic sight words.
[Name] applied spelling patterns to words.
[Name] developed [his/her] understanding of conventions but should continue to pay attention to capitalization and punctuation.
[Name] experimented with commas and quotation marks when writing dialogue.
[His/Her] writing contained a combination of upper- and lowercase letters. Over time, [he/she] should begin to apply them appropriately.
Process
[Name] was able to self-edit and correct [his/her] own grammar or spelling mistakes.
[Name] began to go back and edit [his/her] own work to ensure [his/her] sentences contain complete thoughts.
With guidance and support from adults, [Name] stayed focused on a topic, responded to questions and suggestions from peers, and added details to strengthen writing as needed.
Handwriting
[Name] wrote legibly.
[His/Her] handwriting was neat and legible.
[Name] wrote with small, well-formed print.
[Name] took great pride in her/his handwriting.
[Usually/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], [his/her] writing was difficult to read.
[His/Her] fine motor skills continued to improve this semester.
We supported [Name] to develop proper posture and a correct pencil grasp. This will help [Name] write more legibly and with greater confidence.
[Name] benefited from handwriting support with the school’s occupational therapist.
Speaking and Listening
[Name] actively participated in class discussions.
[Name] listened attentively.
[Name] balanced speaking and listening.
[Name] considered others’ ideas and asked clarifying questions.
[Name] added new ideas or deeper thoughts to what was said before.
[Name] was an articulate student. [He/She] spoke very clearly and confidently in most classroom situations.
[Name] was always eager to share his/her ideas and opinions during discussions.
[Name] made interesting, insightful comments during class discussions.
[His/Her] oral communication skills were strong.
[Name] looked at the speaker and respectfully waited for [his/her] turn.
Occasionally, [Name] was rather soft-spoken. With gentle encouragement, [he/she] used a louder, clearer voice.
[His/Her] speech improved and by the end of the semester [he/she] spoke in a clearer, more articulate voice.
While we commend [his/her] eagerness to share [his/her] ideas with the group, [he/she] frequently needed to be reminded to raise his hand before offering a comment or answering a question.
[Name] was able to stick to one topic of conversation.
[Name] maintained friendly body language during conversations by looking at the speaker, listening respectfully, and smiling.
[Name] was a confident communicator who regularly shared [her/his] ideas during discussions.
[Name] has a keen sense of the world around [him/her]. This was evident during our many conversations.
[Name] shared [his/her] knowledge willingly.
[Name] explained [his/her] point of view effectively.
[Name] listened when other students shared their ideas. In turn, [he/she] effectively added on what was said, successfully contributing to the conversation.
[Name] expressed [his/her] thoughts and ideas with ease.
[Name] expressed [his/her] thoughts and ideas with support.
[Name] spoke confidently.
[Name] spoke clearly.
[Name] could build on others’ ideas with new information.
[Name] respected multiple points of view.
[Name] was willing to learn from new perspectives.
[Name] listened to and respected the view of others.
[Name] accepted that there’s more than one way to look at things.
[Name] was brave and articulate in defending beliefs.
General
[Name] demonstrated [exemplary/thorough/satisfactory/good/basic/limited] understanding of the mathematical concepts explored this semester.
Math was a subject [Name] truly enjoyed.
[Name] was a skilled mathematician who made steady progress this [term/quarter/semester/year].
[Name] acquired many new math skills this [term/quarter/semester/year] and became increasingly self-assured in [his/her] mathematical abilities.
[Name] was an enthusiastic mathematician who was eager to find out what we would be learning each day.
[Name] participated [enthusiastically/consistently/hesistantly/reluctantly] in group discussions and activities at math time.
[His/Her] participation in math was consistent throughout the [term/quarter/semester/year].
[Name] participated fully in group discussions and activities at math time.
With support, [Name] participated in group discussions and activities at math time.

[His/Her] participation in math vastly improved this semester. [He/She] could usually be seen with [his/her] hand up to share an answer or strategy with greater confidence, and [he/she] has found greater success in showing proficiency in new topics that have been introduced.
Although Math was an area of difficulty for [Name], [he/she] maintained a positive attitude and always put forth a great deal of effort.
[Name] was eager to answer questions during whole class instruction and worked hard to clearly articulate [his/her] strategies for solving problems.
[Name] worked hard this [term/quarter/semester/year] to be able to clearly explain [his/her] strategies for solving a problem and has found great success in doing so.
Whenever asked to rephrase [himself/herself], [he/she] was able to give a more straightforward response.
Numeracy
[Name] demonstrated excellent number sense.
[Name] demonstrated strong number sense.
[Name] demonstrated developing number sense.
[Name] counted by 2s, 5s, and 10s.
[Name] identified odd and even numbers.
[Name] compared numbers to determine more/less.
[Name] solved multiplication and division problems.
[Name] added and subtracted to solve equations within 1,000, with or without regrouping.
[Name] was able to add and subtract within 100.
[Name] was able to add and subtract within 50.
[Name] was able to add and subtract within 20.
[Name] used knowledge of math facts to solve equations quickly and accurately.
[Name] continued to develop [his/her] speed and accuracy with addition and subtraction computation, as well as [his/her] ability to read and understand math problems with written language.
[Name] made good use of math manipulatives and the 100s chart to help compute addition and subtraction problems.
[Name] was able to add and subtract 10s.
[Name] used known combinations (addends that make ten, doubles) to solve addition problems.
[Name] demonstrated knowledge of place value.
[Name] effectively solved addition and subtraction problems using regrouping as a strategy.
[Name] figured out the missing number in addition and subtraction equations with unknown parts.

While [Name] had good number sense, [he/she] sometimes doubted [his/her] own abilities and ended up confusing [himself/herself]. At these times, [he/she] sought assistance from the teacher and could usually demonstrate an understanding of the material.
Pattern and function
With assistance in reading a problem or breaking down the steps of an assignment, [Name] was able to do work involving patterns and functions
Measurement and data
During calendar time, [Name] used ordinal numbers (first, second, third, etc.) to describe days of the month.
[Name] was able to tell time to the nearest hour and half hour.
[Name] was still solidifying [his/her] overall understanding of time and could use practice in this area over the summer.
[Name] ordered objects by length.
[Name] organized, represented and interpreted data presented in graphs.
Geometry
[Name] named and described shapes.
[Name] identified and sorted shapes by their attributes.
Problem solving
When solving word problems, [Name] exhibited outstanding problem solving skills.
When solving word problems, [Name] exhibited strong problem solving skills.
When solving word problems, [Name] exhibited good problem solving skills.
When solving word problems, [Name] exhibited developing problem solving skills.
[Name] approached complex problems strategically.
[Name] approached complex problems logically.
[Name] approached complex problems with hesitation. [He/She] benefited from support to break them into smaller steps.
[Name] flexibly applied strategies to problem-solving situations.
[Name] became more of a risk-taker towards the end of the semester and would attempt math that challenged [his/her] own thinking.

[Frequently/Sometimes/Occasionally/At times], [his/her] patience was tested when carrying out challenging math problems. However, with support and encouragement, [he/she] was able to carry out the task successfully.

A strength of [his/hers] was [his/her] ability to think mathematically and apply [his/her] skills to problem solving situations. This is evident not only during math time, but also during class meetings and discussions about a variety of topics including our graphs and the calendar.
Unit of study
It was evident through [his/her] enthusiasm that [Name] enjoyed learning about [enter description].
[Name] greatly enjoyed our [units/units of inquiry/units of study] this [term/quarter/semester/year].
[Name] approached each [unit/unit of inquiry/unit of study] this [term/quarter/semester/year] with [great excitement/excitement/anticipation/hesitation].
[Name] showed interest and curiosity in our [units/units of inquiry/units of study], [unit title] and [unit title].
[Name] showed [exemplary/thorough/satisfactory/good/basic/limited] understanding of ___.
[Name] made relevant observations and connections.
